moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6: We arrive at the classic position of Petrov's Defense.
moves.3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3: This is the main line of the Defense
moves.4... Nxe4 5. d4 Bg4 6. Bd3: Attacking my Knight while developing and getting ready to castle
moves.6... d5 7. O-O Nc6 8. c4 Nxd4: 8. ... dxc4 9. Bxe4 is no good so I take advantage of the pinned knight but I might have been better served to develop the dark squared Bishop with an eye towards castling
moves.9. Qa4+ c6: My first blunder. White's Knight is no longer pinned
moves.10. Nxd4 Qg5: Of course, a bad mistake must be followed by a horrendous blunder.
moves.11. Bxg5: There is no real point in continuing at this stage so I resigned. My d-pawn and Knight are under attack. The Rook can pin my knight if desired. 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. Qxc6+ Bd7 14. Qxa8+ and so on. This is a good example of how quickly a game can be lost with any sort of loose move. Always examine the position and look for your opponents reply before touching anything.
